title: Ekadashi Lecture I Soulful Japa | Sri Madhu Pandit Dasa |  26.09.2023
speaker: HG Madhu Pandit Dasa

segments.key_quote: Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare, Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, setting a spiritual tone.

segments.key_quote: The worship of the Holy Name of the Lord is direct worship of Lord Krishna Himself.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of glorifying and worshipping the holy name of the Lord, stating that it is direct worship of Krishna.

segments.key_quote: There is no difference between Krishna and His name.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that unlike material beings, Krishna's name, form, and personal aspects are non-different from Him, highlighting Krishna's unlimited nature.

segments.key_quote: Krishna and Krishna's name is not different.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the difference between Krishna and humans, explaining that Krishna's body (Sharira) is His soul (Atma), unlike humans where they are distinct.

segments.key_quote: This Shabda is Krishna himself who has appeared before me.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that the sound of the holy name (Shabda) is Krishna Himself, addressing potential doubts about how a sound produced by the tongue can be Krishna.

segments.key_quote: Krishna's Shuddha Nama is Krishna himself.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the concept of Nama Avatara, where Krishna enters the sound of His name, clarifying that Krishna doesn't incarnate into the sound but manifests within it.

segments.key_quote: He is Krishna himself.
segments.summary: The speaker differentiates between an uninstalled and installed deity, explaining that in the latter, Krishna manifests His energetic nature, emphasizing that Krishna reciprocates based on surrender.

segments.key_quote: Krishna is coming down to relate with us, to give us association, to give us realization that He is present before us.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that chanting is done to worship the Nama Avatara, take association, and become liberated from the miseries and modes of material nature, emphasizing Krishna's presence.

segments.key_quote: Nama Prabhu in the form of Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare, Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare reflects His presence onto each of our tongues.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the Nama Avatara as the most expansive incarnation of the Lord in Kali Yuga, emphasizing the need for proper consciousness when God comes before us.

segments.key_quote: Krishna has incarnated to receive my worship and to enter my ear holes.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that Krishna incarnates to receive worship and enter our consciousness, emphasizing the purpose of Nama Avatara is to extract our soul from the complicated mess of material existence and bodily identification.

segments.key_quote: The Supreme Lord loves every soul and he wants every one of us desperately, but he wants a false ego free soul.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that the Lord desires a soul free from false ego and that chanting and hearing are pleasing to the Lord because it serves the purpose of liberation.

segments.key_quote: Anyone who understands this essence, their Prabhupada has given us an order to chant 16 rounds, 16 into 108 times.
segments.summary: The speaker highlights the benefits of understanding the essence of japa, emphasizing Prabhupada's order to chant 16 rounds and how knowing the philosophy helps avoid offenses.

segments.key_quote: The holy name is so powerful, all sins are happening because of ignorance.
segments.summary: The speaker identifies the two main offenses in chanting as blaspheming devotees and inattentive chanting, explaining that sins arise from ignorance and the holy name is merciful and powerful enough to wipe out sinful tendencies.

segments.key_quote: This treasure is God Himself.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that the holy name is the greatest treasure, which is God Himself, and the quality of japa depends on the quality of the background feeling, explaining the difference between conscious and background mind.

segments.key_quote: Background mind should always be in the context of japa.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the background mind should be focused on the context of japa, such as shraddha, the purpose of japa, or feelings of priti, to avoid mechanical chanting.

segments.key_quote: Each chanting of the Hare Krishna, you should think you have earned the pleasure of Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker encourages building up enthusiasm and feeling pleasure with each chanting, emphasizing the importance of humility and chanting with an egoism freed from false egoism.

segments.key_quote: Every card is a relationship with the holy name.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the use of cue cards to meditate on the glory of the Lord and develop feelings associated with japa, explaining how repeated contemplation can transform thoughts into feelings.

segments.key_quote: Good japa is chanting, hearing, feeling the Nama Prabhu.
segments.summary: The speaker draws an analogy with anger to explain how feelings are connected to thoughts, emphasizing that good japa involves feeling the relationship with Nama Prabhu and synchronizing the foreground and background minds for concentration.

segments.key_quote: Chanting will never become mechanical, that is soulful japa.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces a method for practicing soulful japa, involving locking attention through anusarana, sankalpa, and experiencing divya cheshta shakti from the nama, leading to ruchi and ease in chanting.

segments.key_quote: When you get divya cheshta shakti, your chanting and hearing will be like this, in the air.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of moving a finger through air versus paint to illustrate the smoothness achieved with divya cheshta shakti, explaining the importance of anusvarna, arthavat, vidivat, and uninterrupted chanting.

segments.key_quote: It becomes your second nature to lock the attention.
segments.summary: The speaker explains how practicing these principles can train the mind and make it a habit to lock attention on chanting, emphasizing the importance of shraddha and understanding the philosophy to develop the right bhavana.

segments.key_quote: Go following the golden command is ninety percent soulful japa.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by encouraging the audience to begin the second set of sixteen rounds, emphasizing the importance of chanting, hearing, and feeling, and following the golden command for soulful japa.
